questions.text: Which of the following is not an amphipathic Lipid? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triglycerides

 

  • Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids. They consist of three fatty acid chains esterified to a glycerol molecule. These molecules are hydrophobic and do not have a polar or hydrophilic region. Triglycerides are the primary storage form of energy in the body and are commonly found in adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphoglycerol: Phosphoglycerol, also known as phosphoglyceride or glycerophospholipid, is an amphipathic lipid. It has a polar phosphate head group and two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Phosphoglycerides are essential components of cell membranes, where they form the lipid bilayer.

 

Option C. Glycolipids: Glycolipids are amphipathic lipids. They have a hydrophilic carbohydrate (sugar) head group and hydrophobic lipid tails. Glycolipids are important in cell membranes, particularly in nerve cells and the myelin sheath. They play a role in cell signaling and recognition.

 

Option D. Sphingolipids: Sphingolipids are amphipathic lipids. They consist of a sphingosine backbone, a hydrophilic head group (usually containing a sugar), and one or two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Sphingolipids are crucial components of cell membranes and are involved in various cellular processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids, while phosphoglycerol, glycolipids, and sphingolipids are amphipathic and play important roles in cell membrane structure and function.

 

They are formed by esterification between three Fatty acids and one glycerol molecule. As Ester bond is non-polar so, molecule of TG is a non-polar. They are also called as neutral fats.

choices.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

Option A.

 

Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

  • Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

Pityriasis Rosea:

 

  • This is a common skin condition characterized by a herald patch, followed by a distinctive, symmetric rash in a Christmas tree pattern.
  • It primarily affects the back and trunk. The rash is often accompanied by a Collarette scale, where the scale is more prominent at the periphery of the lesion.

 

Christmas Tree Pattern:

 

  • The symmetric distribution and orientation of lesions along the lines of skin cleavage on the back is a hallmark of pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
    • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
    • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Wickham’s Striae - Lichen Planus:

 

  • Wickham's striae are fine, white lines found on the surface of papules in lichen planus.
  • Surface of lichen planus lesions seen with oil on top of lesion reveals these whitish linear streaks.

 

 

  • Lichen planus typically presents with pruritic, purplish, polygonal papules and does not exhibit a Christmas tree pattern.

 

Option C. Christmas Tree Pattern - Lichen Planus:

 

This is incorrect because, although lichen planus is a common dermatologic condition, it does not present with a Christmas tree pattern. This pattern is specific to pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D. Woronoff Ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis:

 

  • The Woronoff ring is a hypopigmented ring surrounding individual psoriatic lesions. It is usually associated with treatment, most commonly UV radiation or topical steroids.

 

 

  • Seborrheic dermatitis presents with greasy, scaly lesions predominantly on the scalp, face, and upper trunk.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When presented with symmetrically distributed, asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on the back in a young adult, consider pityriasis rosea, particularly if the lesions follow a Christmas tree pattern.
  • This pattern, along with the presence of collarette scaling, is highly suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page 35.8, 37.3, 115.9

choices.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
    • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
    • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Other Options

 

Option B: Wickham’s striae - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: Lichen Planus is characterized by pruritic, purple, polygonal papules and plaques. Wickham’s striae are white, lacy lines seen on the surface of lesions, typically not featuring a Christmas tree pattern.

 

 

Option C: Christmas tree pattern - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: While Lichen Planus can have a wide distribution, it does not typically display a Christmas tree pattern, which is specifically associated with Pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D: Wornoff ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis

 

  • Incorrect: Seborrheic Dermatitis typically presents with oily, scaly patches on the scalp, face, and other sebaceous areas, not as a Christmas tree pattern on the back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea is primarily based on the characteristic appearance and distribution of the rash, with the herald patch and subsequent Christmas tree pattern being hallmark features. Awareness of this pattern and the self-limiting nature of the disease helps in reassuring patients and managing expectations regarding the course of the condition

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been admitted with symptoms of altered sensorium and hydrophobia, indicating a potential case of rabies, you have obtained corneal scrapings for further investigation. Now, which test would you select to establish a conclusive diagnosis of the condition? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Viral Culture

 

Altered sensorium and hydrophobia is suggestive of rabies which can be diagnosed by viral culture from corneal scrapings.

 

 

Multiple tests in succession/simultaneously are the best. Usually, Direct Fluorescent Antibody test followed by virus isolation/culture is useful.

 

Virus isolation through culture: best specimens are brain and saliva. CSF, corneal smears and centrifuged urine can also be used.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Serological tests like indirect immunofluorescence are insensitive.

 

Option B: Seller stain for negri bodies can only be demonstrated in brain (pyramidal cells of Ammon's horn, and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum are the most common site).

 

Option D: Real time-PCR Amplification Detection of rabies virus RNA is highly sensitive and specific. This technique can detect virus in fresh saliva samples, skin, CS, and brain tissues. However, it is not confirmatory test.

 

Educational Objective

 

Viral culture from corneal scrapings is the most definitive test for diagnosing rabies in a patient presenting with altered sensorium and hydrophobia.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose:

  • Function: Primary energy source for the brain.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome but is more relevant in conditions like glycogen storage diseases or diabetes.

 

Option B. Lactic acid:

  • Function: Produced during anaerobic metabolism.
  • Relevance: Accumulation is associated with mitochondrial disorders or lactic acidosis, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides:

  • Function: Stored form of energy in adipose tissue.
  • Relevance: Accumulation in the brain is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome; rather, it is associated with lipid storage diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairment and early death in affected children.

questions.text: Which method of diagnosis is shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Darkfield microscopy

 

The given image is of darkfield microscopy as it has a dark background with a refractile organism.

 

Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present. This technique allows for a presumptive diagnosis of syphilis even before antibodies have developed.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Phase contrast microscopy:

 

  • Phase contrast microscopy enhances the contrast of transparent specimens without staining. It is often used for live cells and other transparent samples.
  • The background in phase contrast microscopy is not typically as dark as in darkfield microscopy.

 

Option C. Fluorescent microscopy

 

  • Fluorescent microscopy uses fluorophores to stain specific structures, which then emit light when exposed to specific wavelengths. The images typically show bright fluorescent colors against a dark background.

 

Option D. Electron microscopy

 

  • Electron microscopy uses a beam of electrons to create an image. The images produced are typically in black and white with extremely high resolution, showing detailed structures at the nanoscale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Darkfield microscopy is identified by its characteristic bright specimen against a dark background and is commonly used for diagnosing syphilis through visualization of spirochetes.

questions.text: Which of the following differentials should not be considered for the lesion seen in the image developed in a forest officer?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

 

Eschar can be noted in the given image, and Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is not a possible differential diagnosis for eschar.

  • KFD is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic in South India.
  • The primary clinical manifestations of KFD are fever, headache, severe muscle pain, followed by haemorrhagic symptoms like haemorrhages in the skin, mucosa & viscera, petechial lesions are characteristic skin lesions observed.
  • It is more known for its neurological and hemorrhagic manifestations but NOT Eschar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Scrub typhus (chigger-borne typhus)

 

  • The infective agent of scrub typhus, Orientia tsutsugamushi (Previously known as Rickettsia tsutsugamushi), is conveyed to humans from its natural rodent reservoir by the bites of the Trombiculid mite.

 

 

  • Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers.
  • The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The primary lesion, or eschar, is a firm papule up to 1 mm in diameter surmounted by a vesicle, which dries to form a black crust.

 

Option C: Cutaneous anthrax (Hide porters’ disease)

 

  • Anthrax is a zoonotic infection with Bacillus anthracis.
  • Between 1 and 5 days after infection, an irritable papule develops at the site of inoculation. A bulla on a red oedematous base soon follows.
  • The bulla ruptures and forms a haemorrhagic crust which will undergo necrosis. Surrounding this several satellite lesions filled with serum or yellow fluid are arranged around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar.
  • This is called as Malignant pustule as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D: Healing brown recluse spider bite.

 

Bite of Loxosceles reclusa (Loxoscelism) → Target lesion develops → Development of eschar → Heals with Ulcer formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kyasanur Forest Disease tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever, primarily presenting with haemorrhagic and neurological symptoms, should not be considered for skin lesion, Eschar, unlike the other mentioned differentials.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.33

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 249, 250, 415, 530

choices.text: USG Doppler of right upper limb

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a smoking history of 36 pack years presents with numbness and weakness of the right hand and arm and tingling in the fingers. There is associated drooping of the right eye with miosis. What is the IOC for the patient? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. MRI

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical presentation is pointing towards a diagnosis of right Pancoast or superior sulcus tumor involving the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus.
  • Radiographic findings include an apical mass or unilateral or asymmetrical apical pleural thickening (“apical cap”).
  • Asymmetry in the thickness of an apical cap exceeding 5 mm is considered suggestive.
  • MRI is more accurate than CT in diagnosing brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus involvement, and define the relationship of the tumor to great vessels and the brachial plexus.

 

Regional spread can cause:

 

  • Tracheal obstruction

  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia

  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness

  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea

  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner's syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: While helpful for initial evaluation, it lacks the detail required to assess soft tissue involvement and the exact extent of the tumor.

 

Option B. USG Doppler of right upper limb: Useful for vascular assessment but not suitable for visualizing intrathoracic tumors or their impact on neural structures.

 

Option C. HRCT: High-resolution CT can identify the presence of an apical mass but does not provide as detailed visualization of soft tissue and neurovascular involvement as MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Pancoast tumor, MRI is preferred over other imaging modalities for its superior ability to delineate the extent of tumor involvement with the brachial plexus and sympathetic plexus, critical for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: What type of mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Point mutations

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused due to a point mutation in B globin gene wherein adenine is replaced with thymine in the 6th codon of DNA sequence. Thus, the glutamic acid in the 6th position of beta chain of HbA is changed to valine in HbS. This single amino acid substitution leads to polymerization of hemoglobin molecules inside RBCs. This causes a distortion of cell into sickle shape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insertion: An insertion mutation involves the addition of one or more nucleotide base pairs into the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B. Deletion: A deletion mutation involves the removal of one or more nucleotide base pairs from the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option D. Frameshift mutation: A frameshift mutation is caused by insertions or deletions of a number of nucleotides that are not divisible by three, resulting in a shift in the reading frame of the codons in the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A patient presents with annular lesions on the skin. Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with annular lesions? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urticaria

 

Explanation:

 

Urticaria, commonly known as hives, is characterized by transient, well-circumscribed, erythematous, and edematous plaques that can be pruritic.

 

 

These lesions typically appear and disappear within a few hours and do not usually form annular (ring-shaped) patterns. Urticaria can be triggered by various factors including allergens, stress, or physical stimuli, but the lesions themselves are generally not annular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea corporis: This is a dermatophyte infection that commonly presents as annular, scaly plaques with a well-defined edge and central clearing. These ring-like lesions are characteristic of tinea infections.

 

 

 

Option B. Porokeratosis: This is a disorder of keratinization that presents with annular plaques with a distinct ridge-like border. The characteristic lesion of porokeratosis is an annular plaque with a raised, ridge-like border and central atrophy.

 

 

Option C. Pityriasis rosea: This condition often begins with a single herald patch followed by the development of multiple oval, scaly lesions that may have a ring or annular appearance. The distribution is often in a Christmas-tree pattern on the back.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urticaria is characterized by transient erythematous plaques that do not typically present as annular lesions, unlike conditions such as tinea corporis, porokeratosis, and pityriasis rosea.

questions.text: All among the following are ionizing radiations except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRI


MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) does not use ionizing radiation. Instead, it employs strong magnetic fields and radio waves to generate images of the organs and structures inside the body. This makes MRI an important diagnostic tool, particularly useful for imaging soft tissues without the risks associated with ionizing radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha particles: These are a type of ionizing radiation consisting of helium nuclei and are known to be highly ionizing but with low penetration power.

 

Option B. Gamma rays: Gamma rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation, like X-rays, but typically have even higher energy levels and are certainly ionizing, capable of penetrating deep into biological tissues and causing ionization.

 

Option D. X-rays: X-rays are a well-known form of electromagnetic ionizing radiation used widely in medical imaging to view the structure of the body, particularly bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ionizing Radiation

questions.text: RBC uses which of the following substances during fasting/starvation? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose

 

Under normal physiological conditions, RBCs rely on glucose as their main energy source. Glucose is metabolized through the glycolytic pathway within RBCs to produce ATP, which is essential for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of red blood cells. RBCs lack mitochondria, so they exclusively use anaerobic glycolysis to generate energy from glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketones: RBCs do not utilize ketones as a significant energy source. Ketones are typically used by other tissues like the brain and muscles during prolonged fasting or starvation when glucose levels are low.

 

Option C. Amino acids: While amino acids can be used as an energy source by some tissues during fasting or starvation, RBCs primarily rely on glucose and do not extensively use amino acids for energy production.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: RBCs do not use fatty acids as their primary energy source during fasting or starvation. Fatty acid metabolism primarily occurs in tissues with mitochondria, and RBCs lack these organelles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RBCs always uses glucose whether it is fed state or fasting/starvation state because RBCs lack mitochondria. As ketone body utilization and fatty acid oxidation both take place in mitochondria so, RBCs cannot use fatty acids & ketone bodies as energy source.

 

Table: Substrates utilized for energy production

 

 

  • Fetal heart and also in case of heart failure, main fuel is Glucose.
  • Brain cannot use FA as FAs cannot cross blood brain barrier.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/p 138-139

questions.text: All of the following methods of cold sterilization except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autoclave

 

Cold sterilization refers to sterilization methods that do not involve heat application. Autoclave operates at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, making it a hot sterilization method rather than a cold sterilization technique.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Plasma sterilization: 

 

  • This is a valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses gases in plasma state without temperature increase
  • Effective for heat-sensitive materials

 

Option B. Gamma rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses ionizing radiation
  • Does not increase temperature
  • Commonly used for medical devices and supplies

 

Option C. UV rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses non-ionizing radiation
  • Does not generate heat
  • Effective for surface sterilization

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autoclave is a hot sterilization method operating at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, while plasma sterilization, gamma rays, and UV rays are cold sterilization methods that do not involve heat application.

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HTLV

 

  • HTLV - Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.
  • Oncoviruses are classified as direct or indirect carcinogens, although some overlap exists between the distinction. Direct carcinogenic viruses possess viral oncogenes that directly contribute to neoplastic cellular transformation, whereas indirect carcinogens cause chronic inflammation, which can lead to oncogenic transformation.
  • DNA tumor viruses encode viral oncoproteins which may become integrated into the host cell chromosome.
  • RNA viruses are known to cause microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV (Human Papillomavirus):

 

  • Mechanism: HPV integrates its DNA into the host genome, leading to the production of oncoproteins E6 and E7, which inactivate tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb. This disruption of tumor suppressor pathways contributes to the development of cancers such as cervical cancer.
  • Example: Cervical cancer is a well-documented outcome of HPV infection, particularly with high-risk strains like HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: HBV can integrate its DNA into the host genome, contributing to hepatocellular carcinoma. The integration can lead to genomic instability and the insertional activation of oncogenes or inactivation of tumor suppressor genes.
  • Example: Chronic hepatitis B infection is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: EBV can integrate into the host genome and produce latent proteins that drive cell proliferation and prevent apoptosis. The viral proteins LMP1 and EBNA2 are key players in this process, contributing to the development of various cancers, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Example: EBV is strongly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in endemic areas such as sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:

 

  • Oncogenic DNA Viruses:
    • EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
    • HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8)
    • MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • Oncogenic RNA Viruses:
    • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus)
    • HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)

choices.text: Dilated loops of intestine with valvulae conniventes

questions.text: Which of the following is a finding of large bowel obstruction? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dilated loops with haustrations

 

Explanation:

 

Dilated bowel loops with haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction.

Large bowel obstructions have colonic distension proximal to the obstruction with the distal portion collapsed. The colon is considered dilated if it is more than 6 cm in diameter while the cut off for caecum is 9cm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated loops of intestine with valvulae conniventes: Dilated loops of the intestine with plica circulars (valvulae conniventes) and predominantly central loops are features of the small bowel obstruction. The small bowel is considered dilated if it is more than 3 cm in diameter.

 

Option B. String of pearls sign: The string of pearls sign is also a feature of small bowel obstruction seen in plain radiographs or CT. It represents a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes.

 

Option C. Central dilated bowel loops: While central dilation can occur in any intestinal obstruction, it is more typical of small bowel obstruction where the loops tend to centrally accumulate.

 

Educational Objective:


Identifying dilated loops with haustrations is critical for diagnosing large bowel obstruction, helping differentiate it from small bowel obstruction, which features dilated loops with valvulae conniventes and may show the string of pearls sign.

questions.text: The histopathology picture below is suggestive of? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • The given slide shows a row of tombstones' appearance, which is classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated.

 

 

  • Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3.
  • Hemidesmosomes help in connecting basal layer to underlying dermo-epidermal junction, in pemphigus vulgaris there are no antibodies against Hemidesmosomes, so the basal layer remains attached to the underlying dermo-epidermal junction giving the classical Row of tombstones appearance.
  • The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen.
  • Oral mucosa is commonly affected.

 

 

  • Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.
  • Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back as seen in the image below.

 

 

Biopsy: The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones.

 

 

IMAGE of row of tombstones appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis vulgaris:

 

  • This is an autoimmune disease characterized by hyperproliferation of keratinocytes leading to thickened, scaly plaques.
  • Histologically, it shows parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum), elongation of rete ridges, and a neutrophilic infiltrate (Munro's microabscesses) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not a feature of psoriasis.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis:

 

  • It's a parasitic infection caused by the Leishmania species.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by macrophages containing the parasite (Leishman-Donovan bodies) in the dermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not seen in leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • This is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
  • Histologically, there is an atypical lymphocytic infiltrate in the epidermis (epidermotropism), and the formation of Pautrier's microabscesses (collections of lymphocytes in the epidermis) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It does not exhibit a tombstone appearance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histopathology image suggests Pemphigus vulgaris, which is characterized by intraepidermal blistering due to acantholysis, or separation of keratinocytes, as a result of autoantibody attack on desmosomal proteins.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1

Robbins & cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10e- page no 1160

questions.text: The clinical finding in the 10-year-old boy includes fever, joint pain, and a hand lesion as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules - Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

  • Juvenile dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease affecting the skin and muscles. It typically presents in children with a characteristic skin rash and muscle weakness.
  • Gottron's papules are distinctive red or violet, raised, scaly lesions seen over knuckles (dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints), elbows, knees, and other extensor surfaces, highly suggestive of dermatomyositis.
  • The combination of fever, joint pain, and Gottron's papules strongly indicates juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Other features associated with Dermatomyositis are:

 

  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign: seen in the above image

 

  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual telangiectasias: enlarged capillaries in the nail folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid nodules - Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis:

 

  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder causing chronic joint inflammation in children.
  • Rheumatoid nodules are firm, painless, subcutaneous nodules that usually occur in areas of pressure but are not typically seen in the hands in this form.
  • The lesion in the image doesn't match the typical appearance of rheumatoid nodules.

 

Option C Sclerodactyly - Systemic sclerosis:

 

  • Systemic sclerosis is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and hardening (scleroderma).
  • Sclerodactyly refers to thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers and hands, leading to a claw-like appearance.
  • The lesion shown doesn't indicate the skin thickening or tightness characteristic of sclerodactyly.

 

Option D Mechanic's hand - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease affecting multiple organ systems.
  • Mechanic's hand is a sign associated more with dermatomyositis than SLE, characterized by rough, cracked skin on the sides of the fingers, mimicking the hands of a manual labourer.
  • The presentation of mechanic's hand in SLE is less common and the symptoms described do not align well with SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case involving fever, joint pain, and hand lesions in a child, the presence of Gottron's papules is indicative of Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53 page no 53.1-53.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page 2820-2821

questions.text: What is the likely cause of a disease that is characterized by the occurrence of blistering and peeling affecting over 30% of the body surface area? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drugs

 

Adverse drug reactions can lead to a condition known as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) or its more severe form, Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN), where there is extensive detachment of the epidermis and mucous membrane involvement. This severe reaction typically involves over 30% of the body surface area in TEN. It is a medical emergency and can be life-threatening. The implicated drugs often include allopurinol, certain anticonvulsants, sulphonamide antibiotics, and NSAIDs, among others.

 

As more than 30% of the body surface is involved, the diagnosis is toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Clinical picture will be as shown in the image below.

 

 

SJS Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis classification based on BSA involvement:

 

Based on body surface area (BSA):  

 

 

SJS/TEN is primarily a drug‐induced phenomenon, with a culprit drug being demonstrated in approximately 85% of cases.

 

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN are:

 

  • Allopurinol
  • Carbamazepine
  • Lamotrigine
  • Nevirapine
  • Oxicam (Non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs)
  • Phenobarbital
  • Phenytoin
  • Sulfamethoxazole and other sulfa antibiotics
  • Sulfasalazine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral Infection: Viral infections can indeed cause skin rashes and even blistering in some cases, such as with herpes viruses, including Varicella-zoster virus and Herpes simplex virus. However, they rarely lead to a condition with widespread blistering affecting over 30% of the body surface area.

 

Option C. Fungal Infection: Fungal infections typically cause localized skin changes such as rashes, scaling, and sometimes blistering, but these are usually limited in scope and do not affect such a large proportion of the skin surface as described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Auto-immunity: Autoimmune diseases like pemphigus vulgaris can cause blistering, but they do not usually result in acute widespread skin peeling over 30% of the body surface area. The blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are more superficial and often rupture easily, not typically resulting in extensive peeling.

 

In conclusion, when presented with widespread blistering and peeling of such a significant portion of the skin, drug reactions should be the first consideration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The occurrence of blistering and peeling affecting over 30% of the body surface area is most commonly associated with severe drug reactions, such as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) or Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN).

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition, Chapter 119, Page no 119.13

questions.text: Highest thermic effect?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteins

 

Proteins have the highest thermic effect among the three macronutrients. When you consume protein-rich foods, your body needs to expend more energy to break down and process the proteins. This is because proteins are composed of amino acids, and the body requires energy to convert them into usable forms. The thermic effect of proteins ranges from 20% to 30% of the total caloric intake from protein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have a moderate thermic effect. The thermic effect of carbohydrates ranges from 5% to 10% of the total caloric intake from carbohydrates.

 

Option C. Fats: Fats have the lowest thermic effect among the macronutrients. The thermic effect of fats ranges from 0% to 5% of the total caloric intake from fats.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: Fatty acids are the building blocks of fats, and their thermic effect is similar to that of fats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thermic effect of food (TEF) refers to the increase in energy expenditure that occurs during the digestion, absorption, and metabolism of nutrients in the body. This effect varies depending on the macronutrient composition of the food consumed.

questions.text: A male patient complained of bone and joint pain and was prescribed NSAIDs. After a few days, he returned with vesiculo-bullous lesions that subsequently healed, leaving a brownish discoloration on his face (particularly in the upper lip area), as shown in the image. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fixed drug eruption

 

The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of a Fixed drug eruption. Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common forms of drug induced exanthems.

 

A fixed drug eruption is a known adverse drug reaction characterized by recurrent skin eruptions at the same location upon re-exposure to a specific drug. The vesiculo-bullous lesions followed by brownish discoloration can be seen in fixed drug eruptions, making it the most likely diagnosis given the patient's history of NSAID use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the Plasmodium parasite, which is transmitted to humans via the bites of infected Anopheles mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: Fever (often cyclic), chills, sweating, headaches, muscle pains, fatigue, anemia, jaundice due to hemolysis, and enlargement of the spleen.
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: Malaria does not typically cause vesico-bullous lesions or discoloration of the face.

 

Option B. Dengue:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the dengue virus, which is transmitted through the bite of Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: High fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding (e.g., nose or gum bleed, or easy bruising).
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: While dengue can cause rashes, it does not usually result in vesico-bullous lesions or leave a persistent brownish discoloration on the skin.

 

Option C. Chikungunya fever:

 

A strong differential diagnosis is post chikungunya pigmentation (PCP) of the face seen on the nose & cheeks (Chik Sign) as shown in the below image.

 

 

Why it's not the likely diagnosis: However, this is not the answer because there is no antecedent history of fever, myalgia, or other symptoms suggestive of chikungunya. PCP often appears as the fever subsides and may persist for about three to six months. PCP mimics melasma & may be misdiagnosed If proper history is not taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

 

FDE is a drug eruption distinguished by its recurrence at the same sites on re‐challenge with the same drug, hence their site on the skin is fixed, it has a short latency and is benign in nature.

 

FDE typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.

 

  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply‐defined, round or oval erythematous and edematous plaque which evolves to become dusky, violaceous and occasionally vesicular or bullous.
  • Classically hyperpigmentation occurs after lesions heal. Most common cause:
    • NSAIDs - On Lips
    • Cotrimoxazole - On Genitals

 

Acute onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAID's are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 118 page no 118.11, 118.12

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition pages 141-142, 1633

questions.text: Identify the marked bond in Orange? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrogen bond

 

Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is composed of four deoxyribonucleotides, i.e. deoxyadenylate (A), deoxyguanylate (G), deoxycytidylate (C), and thymidylate (T).

 

These units are linked by 3′ to 5′ phosphodiester bonds (covalent bonds) to form a long polypeptide chain. The nucleotide is formed by a combination of base + sugar + phosphoric acid. The 3′-hydroxyl of one sugar is linked to the 5′-hydroxyl of another sugar through a phosphate group.

 

The DNA strands are held together mainly by hydrogen bonds between the purine and pyrimidine bases. There are two hydrogen bonds between Adenine (A) and Thymine (T) while there are three hydrogen bonds between Cytidine (C) and Guanine (G). The GC bond is therefore stronger than the AT bond.

 

The spatial alignment of the helix allows only purine to pyrimidine base pairing.

 

A-T and C-G base pairs have almost the same shape. A mispairing will disturb the stable double helical structure.

 

 

Other interactions contributing to DNA stability include:

 

  • Hydrophobic effects - DNA has an arrangement wherein the non-polar, uncharged bases are present in the interior of the structure, while the negatively charged phosphates are present on the outside. As the cellular environment is aqueous and polar, the hydrophobic bases in the interior of the helix are kept away from the surrounding water and the hydrophilic heads are exposed and interact with the exterior water. This property increases the solubility of DNA in water.
  • Van der Waals forces - The nitrogenous bases stacked upon one another are spaced based on their van der Waals distance. Van der Waals distance is the distance at which two molecules are attracted to each other. If this distance reduces, the electrons of the two molecules may overlap causing repulsion. These forces are very distance dependent and are inversely proportional to the sixth power of distance (r6). Although a single van der Waals interaction has a very small effect on the overall structure of DNA, the net effect of several interactions leads to substantial stability.
  • Ionic interactions - The electrostatic (ion-ion) repulsion of the negatively charged phosphates on the outside can make DNA potentially very unstable. However, magnesium ions (Mg2+) and cationic proteins along with arginine and lysine residues interact with the negatively charged groups in the DNA and stabilize it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. lonic bond: This type of bond occurs between charged atoms (ions), typically in the form of salts and is not involved in the structure of DNA.


Option B. Covalent bond: Covalent bonds are strong bonds formed by sharing electrons between atoms. In DNA, covalent bonds (phosphodiester bonds) link the sugar-phosphate backbone but are not marked in the provided image.

option D. Phosphodiester Bond: This is a covalent bond that forms the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA. It is not the bond marked in orange in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrogen bonds between purine and pyrimidine bases stabilize the double helix structure of DNA.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be avid on FDG PET scan? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Typical carcinoid

 

Explanation:

 

Typical carcinoids generally do not show avid uptake on an FDG PET scan because they are well-differentiated tumors with relatively low metabolic activity compared to more aggressive cancers. FDG PET scans are most effective in identifying tumors that have high glucose metabolism, which is more characteristic of rapidly growing and less differentiated tumors. Typical carcinoids, being slow-growing, often exhibit minimal FDG uptake, making them less detectable on PET scans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small cell carcinoma: This type of cancer is highly aggressive and shows high metabolic activity, making it usually very avid on FDG PET scans.

 

Option C. Atypical carcinoid: More aggressive than typical carcinoids, often showing intermediate to high FDG uptake due to higher metabolic activity.

 

Option D. Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma: A highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that generally shows significant FDG uptake due to its rapid growth and high metabolic rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumors false-negative on PET-CT:

 

Lung adenocarcinoma

Mucinous adenocarcinoma

Typical carcinoid

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

 

The correct answer is Mutation of tRNA. A suppressor mutation, specifically a tRNA mutation, can reverse the effect of an earlier mutation that produced a premature stop codon. In this scenario, the tRNA undergoes a mutation that allows it to recognize the stop codon (UAA in this case) as if it were a normal codon (e.g., serine's codon UCA). This suppressor tRNA can then insert an amino acid at the site of the stop codon, allowing protein synthesis to continue. This compensates for the earlier mutation that would have led to a truncated, non-functional protein, thereby restoring the wild-type phenotype.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frameshift mutation of coding gene: This type of mutation typically disrupts the reading frame of the gene, leading to widespread changes in the amino acid sequence from the point of mutation onward. It usually results in a non-functional protein and does not suppress the effects of another mutation.

 

Option B. Addition of another normal gene: While adding a normal gene might help correct a phenotype by introducing a functional version of the gene, it does not qualify as a suppressor mutation. This option does not specifically address the reversal of a mutation at the molecular level in the same way as tRNA mutation does.

 

Option C. Deletion of the mutant gene: Deleting the mutant gene would remove the mutation but would not revert the phenotype to wild type by itself. It eliminates the gene's effect entirely rather than compensating for the mutation within the gene or another gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

questions.text: Identify the image? (INCET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subperiosteal abscess

 

The image shown is a cross-sectional CT scan of the head, particularly focusing on the orbit which is highlighting an abnormal finding adjacent to the orbit, which is indicative of a subperiosteal abscess.

 

Subperiosteal Abscess is forms between the orbit's periosteum (a dense layer of vascular connective tissue covering the bones) and the bone. It is usually a complication of sinusitis, especially ethmoid sinusitis, which can lead to infection spreading to the orbital area. On the CT scan, it appears as a localized bulge or collection adjacent to the bone, as shown in the image. This is consistent with the marking on the image indicating a crescent-shaped fluid collection that deforms the normal contour of the orbit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital Cellulitis: This condition involves inflammation and infection of the soft tissues of the orbit behind the orbital septum. However, orbital cellulitis typically involves more diffuse inflammation that would visibly impact more of the orbital tissue on imaging.

 

Option C. Preseptal Cellulitis: This infection involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, without affecting the orbit itself. The condition would not typically show significant findings behind the orbital septum on a CT scan, as seen in the image.

 

Option D. Sinusitis Only: While sinusitis, the inflammation of the sinus linings, can lead to complications such as a subperiosteal abscess, sinusitis itself would typically show thickened sinus linings and air-fluid levels within the sinus cavities on a CT scan, without necessarily involving the orbit unless complicated by adjacent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subperiosteal Abscess is crucial because it requires prompt treatment to prevent potential complications, including vision loss and intracranial spread of infection. Management typically involves antibiotics and may require surgical intervention to drain the abscess.

questions.text: When a codon is changed to stop codon, then it is: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-sense mutation

 

Amino acid codon is replaced by a stop codon causing premature termination of translation and truncated protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop Codons mutation: There are specific codons known as "stop codons" that signal the termination of protein synthesis. These stop codons include UAA, UAG, and UGA. When a ribosome encounters a stop codon, it releases the newly synthesized protein, and protein synthesis comes to an end.

 

Option C. Mis-sense mutation: Codon for one amino acid is replaced by another amino acid codon causing change in protein properties.

 

Option D. Silent mutation: Codon is changed but amino acid is not changed due to codon degeneracy, so no effect on resulting protein.    

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 396

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

choices.text: GI manifestations occurs at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression
Bone marrow suppression appear at doses greater than 1 Gy
Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects
GI manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than neurovascular effects

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding acute radiation syndrome? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. GI manifestations occurs at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression

 

The statement that gastrointestinal (GI) manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression is false. In acute radiation syndrome (ARS), the threshold radiation dose for GI syndrome (8-12 Gy) is higher than that for hematopoietic syndrome, which involves bone marrow suppression (2-8 Gy). Therefore, bone marrow suppression occurs at lower doses compared to GI manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bone marrow suppression appears at doses greater than 1 Gy: This statement is true as bone marrow suppression typically begins to appear at doses around 2 Gy, which is greater than 1 Gy.

 

Option C. Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects: This is true as bone marrow suppression from radiation occurs at lower doses and thus earlier than neurovascular effects, which occur at the highest dose thresholds (12-100 Gy).

 

Option D. GI manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than neurovascular effects: This is true, as GI manifestations appear at a dose range of 8-12 Gy, which is lower than the dose range for neurovascular effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS)

 

  • Occurs with accidental exposure of very high dose radiation
  • Result of nuclear accidents

questions.text: Nail lacquer used in treatment of Onychomycosis among the given options: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tavaborole

 

Tavaborole is a topical nail lacquer used for treating onychomycosis (fungal nail infection). Nail lacquers are specially formulated topical medications that act like nail polish and are designed to penetrate the nail plate. 

 

The common nail lacquers used in onychomycosis can be remembered by the mnemonic "CEAT":

 

 

  • Ciclopirox-olamine (8%)
  • Efinaconazole (10%)
  • Amorolfine (5%)
  • Tavaborole (5%)
  • Terbinafine

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Griseofulvin: It is an oral antifungal medication, not a nail lacquer. It is primarily used for treating tinea capitis and is the drug of choice for dermatophyte infections of the scalp.

 

Option C. Caspofungin: It is an Echinocandin antifungal used for treating systemic fungal infections, not as a topical nail lacquer.

 

Option D. Itraconazole: It is an oral antifungal agent used in systemic therapy of onychomycosis. It is given as pulse therapy: 200mg BD/week for 2 months in fingernail infection and 3 months in toenail infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tavaborole (5%) is one of the approved nail lacquers used as topical therapy in onychomycosis, along with other agents like Amorolfine, Ciclopirox-olamine and Efinaconazole.

questions.text: Mt. Fuji sign is seen in: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumocephalus

 

The Mt. Fuji sign is a radiological sign seen in cases of tension pneumocephalus. Pneumocephalus refers to the presence of air within the cranial cavity. This condition often arises due to trauma, surgical procedures, or infections that introduce air into the intracranial space. The Mt. Fuji sign specifically indicates tension pneumocephalus, where the accumulated air exerts pressure on the brain structures.

 

 

In the Mt. Fuji sign, the frontal lobes of the brain appear to peak sharply, resembling the shape of Mount Fuji. This appearance is due to the air pressure causing the brain to be compressed and elevated at specific points. This sign is crucial for diagnosing tension pneumocephalus because it suggests that the brain is under significant pressure, which can lead to severe complications if not promptly addressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumomediastinum: This condition involves the presence of air in the mediastinum. It is not associated with the Mt. Fuji sign.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition refers to the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, typically due to gastrointestinal perforation or surgical procedures. It does not present with the Mt. Fuji sign.

 

Option D. Pneumothorax: This condition involves the presence of air in the pleural cavity, causing lung collapse. It is unrelated to the Mt. Fuji sign seen in pneumocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mt. Fuji sign is indicative of tension pneumocephalus and is characterized by the peaking of the frontal lobes due to intracranial air pressure.

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA
Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate

 

Anaplerotic reactions are “filling up” reactions or “influx” reactions or “replenishing” reactions which supply 4-carbon units to the TCA cycle.

 

The important anaplerotic reactions are:

 

  1. Pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase enzyme. It needs ATP.
  2. Glutamate is transaminated to alpha keto glutarate; and aspartate to oxaloacetate.
  3. Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate by NADP+ dependent malic enzyme.

 

The citric acid cycle acts as a source of precursors of biosynthetic pathways, e.g., heme is synthesized from succinyl CoA and aspartate from oxaloacetate. To counterbalance such losses, and to keep the concentrations of the 4-carbon units in the cell, anaplerotic reactions are essential. This is called anaplerotic role of TCA cycle (Greek word, ana = up; plerotikos = to fill)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA: This is not an anaplerotic reaction; it is a part of the link between glycolysis and the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetaldehyde: This reaction is part of ethanol fermentation, not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Option D. Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid: This is part of anaerobic glycolysis (fermentation), not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplerotic reactions, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, are crucial for maintaining the levels of TCA cycle intermediates, enabling the cycle to function efficiently and support biosynthetic demands.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alkaptonuria

 

Explanation:

 

Intervertebral disc calcification is seen in the image suggestive of alkaptonuria.

 

Deficiency: Homogentisic oxidase

 

Hyperpigmentation of ears and eyes suggestive of ochronosis is a clue. It is seen due to excessive build-up of homogentisic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis): Features ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebral bodies, often with a "candle wax dripping" appearance, distinct from the findings in alkaptonuria.

 

Option B. Fluorosis: Typically presents with increased bone density and ossification of interosseous ligaments, not specifically associated with hyperpigmentation or the disc calcifications shown.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Characterized by a "bamboo spine" appearance due to bony fusion, seen in younger patients (less than 50 years old), which does not typically include hyperpigmentation or the type of disc calcification seen in alkaptonuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alkaptonuria - Is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic oxidase
  • Fluorosis – Increased bone density with interosseous ligament ossification 
  • DISH VS   Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: In MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methionine

 

  • Methionine is not restricted in MSUD. MSUD is characterized by the inability to break down three specific branched-chain amino acids: Leucine, Isoleucine, and Valine. Methionine is not one of the amino acids that are restricted in the diet of individuals with MSUD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valine: Valine is one of the amino acids restricted in MSUD. People with MSUD need to limit their intake of Valine as their bodies cannot properly metabolize it.

 

Option C. Leucine: Leucine is another amino acid that is restricted in MSUD. It is one of the three branched-chain amino acids that individuals with MSUD need to limit in their diet.

 

Option D. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is also restricted in MSUD. Like Valine and Leucine, Isoleucine is a branched-chain amino acid that individuals with MSUD need to restrict to manage the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid Decarboxylase resulting in defect in oxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acids Valine, Isoleucine and leucine. As a result, these amino acids accumulate and are excreted in urine. So, for the treatment, these BCAA should be restricted in diet.

 

Methionine is a sulphur containing amino acid and do not require this enzyme for its metabolism. So, its restriction is not required in MSUD.  

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 290

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition exhibited by A. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Competitive inhibition

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the active site of the enzyme. In the given graph, the presence of inhibitor A results in an increase in Km (Michaelis constant), indicating decreased enzyme affinity for the substrate due to competition. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged, which is characteristic of competitive inhibition. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows that the lines intersect on the y-axis, confirming that Vmax is unaffected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive inhibition: This type of inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a decrease in both Km and Vmax. The lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot are parallel, unlike the competitive inhibition plot seen here.

 

Option C. Mixed inhibition: In mixed inhibition, the inhibitor can bind to both the enzyme alone and the enzyme-substrate complex. This results in changes to both Km and Vmax, depending on the binding affinity. The graph shows altered Vmax with an intersection that is not on the y-axis, differing from competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. Non-competitive inhibition: Non-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds to a site other than the active site, affecting the enzyme regardless of substrate binding. This results in decreased Vmax without altering Km, seen as lines intersecting on the x-axis in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, unlike the competitive inhibition pattern here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition is identified by an increased Km and unchanged Vmax, with intersecting lines on the y-axis of the Lineweaver-Burk plot

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with generalized fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst over the past few months. He mentions that he has also been experiencing muscle weakness and occasional abdominal discomfort. His abdomen spine X-ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperparathyroidism

 

The presented clinical scenario and X-ray reveal widespread calcification in both kidneys, indicating a condition known as nephrocalcinosis, often associated with hyperparathyroidism.

 

Nephrocalcinosis is characterized by the accumulation of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, and it commonly arises from conditions that lead to elevated calcium levels, such as hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that causes copper accumulation in tissues, leading to neurological and hepatic symptoms. It does not typically present with nephrocalcinosis or the specific set of symptoms described, such as muscle weakness and abdominal discomfort related to calcium imbalance.

 

Option B. Addison's disease: This condition involves adrenal insufficiency and can present with fatigue and abdominal pain but is not associated with nephrocalcinosis. It also does not explain the hypercalcemia indicated by kidney calcifications in the X-ray.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Primarily affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to thick mucus secretions and digestive complications. It is not associated with kidney calcifications or the hormonal imbalances of the parathyroid gland as seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Widespread kidney calcifications seen on X-ray, coupled with symptoms of fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst, are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. This condition results from excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone, leading to elevated blood calcium levels and subsequent calcium deposition in organs like the kidneys (nephrocalcinosis).

questions.text: A South Asian fruit farmer presented with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

 

The Nipah virus is known to be transmitted by fruit bats, specifically the Pteropus species, which are commonly found in South Asia. The virus can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis in humans, symptoms that match the presentation in this case (fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis). The close association between fruit farming and fruit bats increases the risk of transmission, especially in South Asia where the Nipah virus is more prevalent.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is known for causing fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. It does not cause severe respiratory symptoms or encephalitis as described in this case.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium species and transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. It presents with fever, chills, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically cause breathlessness or encephalitis.

 

Option D. Ebola virus: Although Ebola can be associated with bats, it primarily causes hemorrhagic fever and is less associated with respiratory symptoms or encephalitis compared to Nipah virus. Also, Ebola is more commonly linked with direct human-to-human transmission or through contact with infected animals' bodily fluids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nipah virus should be considered when a patient, especially in South Asia, presents with fever, respiratory symptoms, and encephalitis, and has a history of exposure to fruit bats

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hiatal hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Retrocardiac air fluid level is seen on CXR which is suggestive of a hiatal hernia. It is defined as the displacement through esophageal hiatus of GE junction or other parts of the stomach into the thoracic cavity

 

 

IOC for hiatal hernia: Contrast enhanced CT + oral contrast (Iohexol most commonly) (to determine obstruction/ Volvulus)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bochdalek hernia: This is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia typically occurring at the posterolateral part of the diaphragm, not associated with the retrocardiac region.

 

Option B. Morgagni hernia: Another type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia that occurs anteriorly at the sternocostal triangles, not retrocardiac.

 

Option D. Eventration of diaphragm: Involves an abnormal elevation of the diaphragm muscle, not typically presenting as an air-fluid level in the retrocardiac area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hiatal hernia can be diagnosed on plain chest X-ray when an air-fluid level is visible in the retrocardiac area, indicating herniation of stomach contents into the thorax through the esophageal hiatus. Contrast-enhanced CT with oral contrast is the imaging of choice for further evaluation, particularly to assess for any complications like obstruction or volvulus.

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans A) Ca2+

 

  • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.

 

Option C. Glucose:

 

  • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):

 

  • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers Pi, uses PLP (B6) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms of dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

The patient's symptoms—dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline (dementia)—represent the classic triad of pellagra, which is associated with niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is commonly summarized as the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. In severe untreated cases, it can lead to a fourth "D," which is death. Niacin deficiency can occur due to poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or conditions that affect tryptophan metabolism, such as Hartnup disease and carcinoid syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to beriberi, which manifests as dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy) or wet beriberi (cardiac failure). It can also cause Wernicke's encephalopathy and Korsakoff's psychosis, particularly in alcoholics, but it does not cause dermatitis or diarrhea.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency is associated with symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, depression, and seizures. It does not typically cause the 3D symptoms seen in pellagra unless it indirectly leads to niacin deficiency by impairing tryptophan metabolism.

 

Option D. Retinol: Retinol (vitamin A) deficiency primarily affects vision, immune function, and skin health, causing conditions like night blindness and xerophthalmia, but it does not cause diarrhea or cognitive decline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is primarily caused by niacin deficiency.

questions.text: Identify this sign on USG: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seashore sign

 

Explanation:


The image shows the "Seashore sign" on M-mode ultrasound, which is used primarily to evaluate for lung sliding. The seashore sign is characterized by a sandy or granular pattern in the lower half of the M-mode display, beneath the pleural line. This pattern is caused by the motion of the lung relative to the pleura during breathing. It is a normal finding, indicating that the lung is sliding smoothly against the parietal pleura, which helps rule out conditions like pneumothorax in the area scanned.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stratosphere sign: Also known as the "barcode sign," it appears as parallel lines in M-mode and is associated with the absence of lung sliding, often seen in cases of pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Lung point sign: This is seen in lung ultrasound as the point at which the normal seashore sign of lung sliding transitions to the stratosphere sign in cases of pneumothorax. It is specific for pneumothorax but not depicted in this ultrasound image.

 

Option D. Sinusoidal sign: Typically refers to a waveform pattern seen in various types of medical imaging and monitoring, not relevant to the depiction of lung sliding on ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung sliding- seen at the pleural lining due to relative motion between pleural layer. Seashore sign- M mode counterpart of lung sliding. Motion of the lung deep to the pleura causes grainy appearance in M-mode, stimulating sand in a seashore.

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

 

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a widely used method to amplify specific DNA segments. The process involves three main steps that are repeated in cycles, resulting in the exponential amplification of the target DNA sequence.

 

Steps of PCR:

 

 

The steps of 1, 2 and 3 are repeated results in the exponential amplification of DNA segments of defined length. In each cycle, the DNA strands are doubled. Thus 20 cycles provide for 1 million times amplifications. These cycles are generally repeated by automated instrument, called Thermal cycler.

 

After the amplification procedure, DNA hybridization technique or Southern blot analysis with a suitable probe, shows the presence of the DNA in the sample tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is Denaturation, Annealing, and Extension. These steps are repeated in cycles to exponentially amplify the target DNA segment.

questions.text: After administering the patch test to a 10-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis, when should you schedule his return for patch removal? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48 hours

 

The Gold standard Diagnostic test for Airborne contact dermatitis (ABCD) & Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is a patch test. 

 

Patch testing:

 

  • It is a method used to determine if a specific substance causes allergic inflammation of a patient's skin.
  • It is typically indicated for patients with suspected allergic contact dermatitis.
  • The test involves the application of various substances in small chambers or patches to the skin, usually on the back.
  • After the application of a patch test, the patches are generally removed at 48 hours (2 days), and an initial reading is taken.
  • This timeframe allows for the elicitation of a Type IV or delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is the basis of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • However, readings at 48 hours may not be sufficient to detect all reactions, and thus an additional reading at 96 hours is often recommended.
  • The additional reading helps to identify late reactions, which could otherwise be missed if only the 48-hour reading is considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours

 

  • This timeframe is too short for most delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions to occur.
  • Removing the patches at 24 hours would likely result in missing many positive reactions.

 

Option B. 72 hours

 

  • It is not typically when the patches are first removed.
  • The patches are usually removed at 48 hours, and the skin is then inspected for any reactions.

 

Option D. 96 hours

 

  • This is a common time for a follow-up reading and not the initial removal of the patches.
  • Some protocols suggest readings at this time to ensure that late-appearing reactions are not missed.

 

The image below shows a patch test:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Rooks textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.23

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 406

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3900336/

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

 

The clinical features described are suggestive of McArdle's disease (glycogen storage disease type V), which is caused by a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase. This enzyme deficiency leads to an inability to break down glycogen into glucose in the muscle cells, resulting in exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and accumulation of glycogen in muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle-debranching enzyme:

  • Deficiency: Causes Cori's disease (glycogen storage disease type III).
  • Clinical Features: Highly branched dextrin accumulates in liver and muscle, leading to fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and myopathy.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in the debranching process of glycogenolysis, but the primary symptoms are different from those described in the question.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase 1:

  • Deficiency: Causes Tarui's disease (glycogen storage disease type VII).
