  • Clinical Features: Exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and myoglobinuria, similar to McArdle's, but also includes hemolytic anemia due to the enzyme's role in glycolysis in red blood cells.
  • Note: This enzyme is involved in glycolysis, not directly in glycogen metabolism.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase:

  • Deficiency: Causes Von Gierke's disease (glycogen storage disease type Ia).
  • Clinical Features: Fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.
  • Note: This enzyme deficiency affects the liver's ability to release glucose, but not directly linked to muscle symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male underwent NCCT abdomen for suspected renal calculi. An incidental finding was noted in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydatid cyst

 

Explanation:

 

The above CT image showing a calcified lesion in the liver with a lamellar wall which indicates hydatid disease.

 

Caused by Echinococcus granulosus → Humans – accidental host

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Typically presents as a solid tumor with irregular borders and might show vascular invasion or enhancement after contrast administration, not typically calcified.

 

Option B. Fibronodular hyperplasia: Refers to a benign liver lesion that generally does not demonstrate the clear, calcified, and layered appearance of a hydatid cyst.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: Would more likely present as a fluid-filled lesion with possible air-fluid levels and peripheral enhancement after contrast, not the lamellar calcification seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydatid cysts in the liver are recognized on CT scans by their calcified, lamellar structure and are an important differential when considering cystic liver lesions, particularly in regions where Echinococcus is endemic.

questions.text: Which of the following causes aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus

 

ParvoVirus-B19 infects erythroid progenitor cells and inhibits erythropoiesis, leading to acute erythroblastopenia and reticulocytopenia. The bone marrow in patients with transient aplastic crisis is characterized by an absence of maturing erythroid precursors and presence of giant pro-normoblasts. Although giant pro-normoblasts are suggestive of parvovirus B19 infection, they are not diagnostic of the disease. Aplastic crisis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis is because of pancytopenia accompanied with a marked decrease in reticulocytes. Bone marrow aspiration may not be routinely required when viral infection-induced aplastic crisis is highly suspected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poxvirus: Poxviruses are not associated with causing aplastic crisis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus: While Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can cause hematologic abnormalities, it is not typically associated with causing aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus: Adenovirus infections are common but are not known to cause aplastic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent for aplastic crisis in patients with hereditary spherocytosis. It infects erythroid progenitor cells, inhibiting erythropoiesis and leading to a significant decrease in reticulocytes, causing acute erythroblastopenia.

questions.text: A patient had complaints of ureteric colic. Examination was normal. What is the best imaging to diagnose? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NCCT KUB


Non-contrast computed tomography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (NCCT KUB) is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing ureteric colic. Around 90% of ureteric or renal stones are radio-opaque and appear hyperdense on CT, allowing even small stones to be detected effectively. NCCT KUB is highly sensitive and specific for urinary calculi.

 

MRI is not typically used for urinary calculi due to poor visualization of stones. Ureteroscopy is an invasive procedure, generally performed for treatment rather than diagnosis. CECT (contrast-enhanced CT) is used primarily for detecting renal masses, infections, or inflammatory conditions, not for detecting stones, as stones appear hyperdense without contrast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: Not indicated for urinary calculus diagnosis. MRI is less effective in visualizing stone composition and location compared to CT.

 

Option B. Uretroscopy: An invasive procedure used for treatment, not diagnosis. It is not recommended as a primary diagnostic tool for stone detection.

 

Option D. CECT KUB (Contrast Enhanced CT): Typically used when suspecting renal masses, inflammatory pathologies, or neoplastic conditions. For stone diagnosis, contrast is unnecessary because stones are already hyper-dense and clearly visible on non-contrast scans.

 

Educational Objective: 


NCCT KUB is the best imaging modality for diagnosing ureteric colic and detecting renal calculi due to its high sensitivity for hyperdense stones.

choices.text: No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

questions.text: A resident had a needle stick injury while dealing with a Hepatitis B positive patient. Serology was done and HBsAg was negative and the Anti-HBs was >105 mIU/ml. What is the next step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

 

No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination: The resident's serology shows that HBsAg is negative and Anti-HBs is greater than 105 mIU/ml, which indicates that he has sufficient immunity against Hepatitis B from prior vaccination. No further treatment is necessary because the antibody titres are already protective.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Booster dose of vaccine: Not required since the resident already has sufficient antibody levels indicating immunity.

 

Option B. Immunoglobulin with full vaccination: This would be necessary if the resident had low or no detectable antibody titres, indicating no prior immunity.

 

Option C. Repeat full course of vaccine: Not necessary because the resident already has adequate antibody titres indicating immunity.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient
Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband
Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present
Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

questions.text: A female patient presents with active genital warts with a history of recurrence, but her husband doesn't have it. What advice will you give to prevent transmission? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

 

  • This is the correct answer. Avoiding sexual contact when active lesions are present is one of the most effective ways to prevent the transmission of HPV.
  • Genital warts are primarily caused by specific types of human papillomavirus (HPV-6 and HPV-11).
  • These warts, also known as venereal warts or condyloma acuminata, are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact.
  • However, they can also be transmitted through non-sexual means.
  • Genital warts are highly contagious when lesions are active, so abstaining from sexual activity during these times is crucial to prevent spread to partners.

 

 

Management of Genital warts:

 

  • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are the primary drugs recommended as first-line treatments for genital warts. Imiquimod stimulates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, inducing apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • Imiquimod cream is approved for the treatment of actinic keratoses, superficial basal cell carcinoma, and genital warts through topical immunomodulation
  • The most effective method to prevent the transmission of infection is to abstain from sexual intercourse when active lesions are present.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient.

 

  • This is not the correct approach because continuous prophylaxis with antivirals is not typically recommended for genital warts, which are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • Antivirals are more commonly used for other viral infections like herpes simplex virus.
  • Moreover, prophylaxis doesn't prevent the transmission of HPV during periods without active lesions.

 

Option B. Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband.

 

  • This option is incorrect for similar reasons as option A. HPV, the virus causing genital warts, does not have a prophylactic antiviral treatment.
  • Furthermore, since the husband does not have active lesions or a history of genital warts, prophylactic treatment is not indicated.

 

Option C. Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present.

 

  • While this might seem like a reasonable approach, it is important to note that antivirals are not effective against HPV.
  • Treatment for active genital warts typically involves topical agents or procedures like cryotherapy, not systemic antiviral medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent the transmission of genital warts caused by HPV, it is advisable to avoid sexual intercourse when active lesions are present, as there are no effective antiviral prophylaxis options for HPV, and HPV transmission risk is highest during periods with active lesions.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 318

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10 E page no 998

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

 

It is a chronic deep cutaneous fungal infection usually affecting the limbs at the inoculation site

 

Causative agents include several fungi found in soil, wood and decaying plant material:

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosi (most common pathogen, accounts for > 90% of the cases in South America)
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Cladosporium carrionii
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa (Ramichloridium cerophilum)

 

Common clinical presentation is verrucous lesion over extremities of adult men engaged in outdoor work. Lesion starts as a small firm red / gray bump on the traumatized skin on the foot or hand. Grows slowly (2 mm/year) to form raised hyperkeratotic (crusted, warty-looking) plaque

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It typically presents with flu-like symptoms, skin lesions, and sometimes lung involvement. The histopathology would show broad-based budding yeast rather than medlar bodies.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: This refers to a group of fungal infections caused by dematiaceous (dark-walled) fungi. The infection can present in various forms, from superficial to deep infections, but it does not typically produce medlar bodies.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, this infection usually follows a thorn prick and presents as nodular lesions that can ulcerate. The characteristic histopathological finding is cigar-shaped yeast, not medlar bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury, with histopathological evidence of medlar bodies.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given image? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospira

 

The organisms in the image are leptospira.

 

In spirochetes, the presence of two axial filaments (periplasmic flagella) with polar insertions are located in periplasmic space called as endoflagella, which are responsible for the characteristic corkscrew motion of these bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Vibrio species are comma-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, commonly known for causing cholera (Vibrio cholerae).

 

Option C. Helicobacter: Helicobacter pylori are spiral-shaped bacteria known for causing stomach ulcers and are Gram-negative.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Salmonella species are rod-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, known for causing foodborne illnesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospira is identified by its spiral morphology with axial filaments (endoflagella) and is a type of spirochete, along with Treponema and Borrelia.

 

Endoflagella are seen in:

 

  • Treponema
  • Borrelia
  • Leptospira

questions.text: Vitamin K in its coenzyme form is regenerated by the enzyme? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epoxide reductase

 

Vitamin K plays a crucial role in the carboxylation of glutamic acid residues in proteins to form gamma-carboxyglutamate, which is important for blood clotting. The active form of vitamin K is required for this carboxylation reaction. After participating in the carboxylation reaction, vitamin K is converted to its epoxide form. To be reused, this epoxide form must be converted back to its active hydroquinone form.

 

The enzyme epoxide reductase is responsible for this conversion. It reduces vitamin K epoxide back to the active hydroquinone form, thus regenerating the coenzyme form of vitamin K. This process is essential for the continuous availability of active vitamin K for carboxylation reactions.

 

 

Fig: Vitamin K cycle.

 

Dicoumarol - a structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutathione reductase: This enzyme is involved in the reduction of glutathione disulfide to glutathione, and is not involved in the regeneration of vitamin K.

 

Option B. Quinone reductase: This enzyme reduces quinones to hydroquinones but is not specifically responsible for the regeneration of vitamin K's active form.

 

Option C. Vitamin K reductase: While it plays a role in the vitamin K cycle, the specific enzyme responsible for regenerating the coenzyme form of vitamin K from its epoxide form is epoxide reductase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epoxide reductase regenerates the active coenzyme form of vitamin K from its epoxide form, ensuring the continuous availability of active vitamin K for critical carboxylation reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: In the case of an elderly male presenting with meningitis, a gram stain of the CSF sample shows the presence of gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following statements accurately pertains to the motility of the responsible microorganism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C

 

  • The provided case involves an elderly man with meningitis, and the smear analysis indicates the presence of a gram-positive bacillus, strongly indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria exhibits motility at 25°C but loses its ability to move at 37°C.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES

 

  • Motility: shows differential motility, which is due to temperature dependent flagella expression) 
    • Tumbling type of motility at 25°C
    • Non-Motile at 37°C
  • Culture → Blood agar, Chocolate agar
  • Selective media → PALCAM agar

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Meningitis → DOC → Ampicillin in combination with gentamicin for synergistic effect
  • Penicillin allergy → Cotrimoxazole
  • In febrile gastroenteritis → Amoxicillin

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes exhibits motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

 

The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

 

  • Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.
  • The commonly implemented methods for identifying Candida are 10% potassium hydroxide stain and culture with sabouraud dextrose agar. Differentiation of specific species is possible with special culture mediums like CHROMagar Candida. 
  • ELISA and PCR tests are used in cases of invasive candidiasis and to differentiate Candida dubliniensis from Candida albicans.
  • It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.
  • It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

 

Option C. Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

 

Option D. Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudo membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Botulinum

 

The image given above depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin.

 

Clostridium botulinum is non-invasive. Its pathogenesis is due to the production of powerful neurotoxin ‘botulinum toxin’ (BoNT). It produces flaccid paralysis. There are 7 serological types of botulinum neurotoxin labeled as types A, B, C [C1 C2], D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is caused mainly by types A, B, E and F (rarely).

 

After entry (either ingested, inhaled, or produced in a wound), botulinum toxin is transported via the blood to peripheral cholinergic nerve terminals. The most common nerve terminal sites are neuromuscular junctions, postganglionic parasympathetic nerve endings, and peripheral ganglia. It does not affect the CNS.

 

Botulinum toxin causes proteolysis of snare proteins that are required for the excocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles, thereby preventing the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the peripheral nerve endings, including neuromuscular junctions (presynaptic inhibition). This results in a lack of stimulus to the muscle fibers, irreversible relaxation of the muscles to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal, and flaccid paralysis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Tetanus: Tetanus toxin (produced by Clostridium tetani) acts by inhibiting neurotransmitter release in the central nervous system by cleaving synaptobrevin, another SNARE protein, but it causes spastic paralysis rather than flaccid paralysis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Diphtheria toxin (produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae) inhibits protein synthesis in host cells by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2), which is a completely different mechanism from that of botulinum toxin.

 

Option D. Pertussis: Pertussis toxin (produced by Bordetella pertussis) modifies the signaling of G-protein coupled receptors by ADP-ribosylating the Gi protein, thereby affecting cellular communication but not directly impacting acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by preventing the release of acetylcholine at peripheral nerve endings through the proteolysis of SNARE proteins necessary for acetylcholine vesicle exocytosis.

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount.

 

Lab Diagnosis for Trichomonas:

 

  1. Direct Microscopy: Wet (saline) mount of fresh samples jerky motile trophozoites and pus cells. Cystic stage not seen.
  2. Culture: Gold standard method for diagnosis.
  3. Serology: Antigen Detection in Vaginal Secretion:
    • More sensitive than microscopy
    • Indicates recent infection
    • ELISA uses monoclonal antibodies.
    • Antibody Detection by ELISA - whole cell antigen preparation
  4. Molecular Methods: Highly sensitive targeting T. vaginalis specific genes - beta-tubulin gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be cultured: Incorrect, as Trichomonas vaginalis can indeed be cultured and this is considered the gold standard for its diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions: Incorrect, Trichomonas vaginalis does not produce cysts; it exists only in trophozoite form.

 

Option D. It is not a sexually transmitted infection: Incorrect, as it is a well-known sexually transmitted infection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Among the listed causes of alopecia, which one(s) result in non-scarring alopecia? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, and 3

 

 

Non cicatricial alopecia classification:

 

 

Option 1 - Alopecia areata:

 

  • It is a persistent autoimmune condition characterized by non-scarring hair loss patches.
  • This inflammatory disease involves T cells and primarily affects individuals with genetic susceptibility, being associated with HLA DR4, DR5, DQ3.
  • The condition is identifiable by "exclamation mark hairs" – short, fragile hairs that taper toward the base, as illustrated in the image below.

 

 

  • Alopecia totalis refers to the complete loss of scalp hair.
  • Alopecia universalis involves the loss of all body hair.
  • In instances of limited alopecia areata, approximately 80% of patients experience spontaneous remission.
  • Alopecia areata predominantly affects pigmented hair.
  • In older individuals, gray hair may consist of both white and colored hair. If the disease progresses rapidly, only the colored hair will be affected and lost, leaving the white hair unaffected in the patches of hair loss.
  • This sudden change in hair color is known as "Turning white overnight".

 

The following image depicts sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

Fig: Alopecia areata " Turning white overnight"

 

Option 2 - Telogen effluvium:

 

  • It is an acute onset of scalp hair loss that starts one to two months after a trigger, such as a high fever, infections (Cholera, Typhoid, Covid), trauma from surgery or other trauma, starvation, MI, Pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • It refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.
  • Telogen hair shedding that lasts longer than six months is known as chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.
  • Thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency Anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition are the main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.

 

Option 3 - Androgenetic Alopecia

 

  • The disorder known as androgenetic alopecia is characterized by the miniaturization & reduction of hair follicle production.
  • Male pattern hair loss and female pattern hair loss are the two types.
  • Recession of the frontal hairline and vertex thinning are seen in male pattern hair loss.
  • Females may experience male pattern hair loss, and the opposite is also true.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option 4 - Frontal fibrosing alopecia

 

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a scalp condition that affects post-menopausal women in particular and frequently involves the eyebrows.
  • It is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-scarring alopecia’s do not destroy the hair follicle and allow for the possibility of hair regrowth.
  • Scarring alopecia’s involve destruction and replacement of the hair follicle with scar tissue, leading to permanent hair loss.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.25, 28, 33

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Online resource: https://www.bmj.com/content/347/bmj.f6112

questions.text: Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sclerotic body

 

The histopathological picture shows brown coloured thick walled round cells that have transverse septations within them. These are called as Sclerotic bodies, also known as muriform cells or Medlar bodies, or copper penny appearance a found in tissue biopsies of patients with chromoblastomycosis. These bodies are a key diagnostic feature of this fungal infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Budding yeast: This is a general term for yeast cells reproducing through budding. It is not pathognomonic for a specific disease without further context.

 

Option C. Negri body are intracytoplasmic, round purplish structures with basophilic inner granules. They are pathognomic of rabies.

 

 

Option D. Asteroid body are oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. They are antigen-antibody complexes deposits. Seen in sporotricosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Few Important Pathognomonic structures associated with disease:

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 m) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoisospora

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as Cystoisospora.

 

Points in favor:

 

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with Kinyoun staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclospora: Cyclospora oocysts are smaller (8-12 µm) and round, with variable acid-fast staining. They sporulate in soil and contain two sporocysts with two sporozoites each.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are even smaller (4-6 µm) and round. They are uniformly acid-fast and contain four sporozoites. Sporulation occurs inside the host cell.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are obligate intracellular parasites that do not have the same oocyst structure as coccidian parasites. They are detected by different staining methods and appear as small spores rather than larger oocysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

questions.text: Sodium benzoate is given for urea cycle defects for scavenging ammonia. Which amino acid donates amino group to the scavengers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine

 

Sodium benzoate acts as an ammonia scavenger in urea cycle disorders. It works by conjugating with glycine to form hippurate (or hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine. This process provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion when the urea cycle is impaired. The reaction occurs without requiring the urea cycle, thus helping to reduce ammonia levels in patients with urea cycle disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine: Arginine is actually a component of the urea cycle itself and is often supplemented in some urea cycle disorders (except arginase deficiency). It does not directly conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia removal.

 

Option C. Glutamine: Glutamine is involved with another ammonia scavenger, phenyl butyrate, which is converted to phenyl acetate and then conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine. However, glutamine does not conjugate with sodium benzoate.

 

Option D. Aspartate: Aspartate is an amino acid that participates in the urea cycle by providing one of the nitrogen atoms for urea formation. It does not conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urea cycle disorders, sodium benzoate is used as an ammonia scavenger that conjugates specifically with glycine to form hippurate (hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty following blunt trauma to the chest. A chest X-ray was done. Among the following radiographs, in which case would you further evaluate the patient before putting a chest tube? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3,4

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pneumothorax
  2. Hemothorax
  3. Consolidation
  4. Diaphragmatic hernia

 

Image 3: Consolidation would be managed symptomatically and chest tube shouldn’t be inserted.

 

Image 4: Diaphragmatic hernia: A direct blow to the diaphragm can cause it to rupture, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the chest. In the case of stomach herniation into the chest, a nasogastric tube followed by chest radiography can be helpful. Video-assisted thoracoscopy or laparoscopy is the most accurate investigation.

 

Other Options:

 

Radiographs 1-2 show hemothorax and pneumothorax. Intercostal chest drains should be inserted into the fifth intercostal space. The safe landmark is a triangle anterior to the midaxillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of blunt chest trauma, careful evaluation of chest radiographs is crucial. Consolidations (Image 3) and diaphragmatic hernias (Image 4) require specific management strategies distinct from those of pneumothorax or hemothorax, where immediate chest tube placement is standard.

choices.text: E1, E2, E5
E6, E7
L1, L2

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E6, E7

 

The image shows the life cycle of the human papilloma virus, and the E6 and E7 proteins act as oncogenes

 

 

  • HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 deregulate host cell cycle by binding and inactivating tumor suppressor genes p53 and pRb.
  • Binding of E6 gene to p53 causes degradation of p53.
  • E7 gene binds to pRb and disrupts the complex between pRb and E2F leading to uncontrolled proliferation. HPV, human papilloma virus.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

choices.text: Reassure and to check whether passed in stools

questions.text: A child presents with history of acute dysphagia. CXR is shown below. What is the next best step? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Remove endoscopically

 

Explanation:

 

The given CXR shows a foreign body in the esophagus which is likely to be a button battery as seen by the double margins.

 

 

In profile/ en face: Foreign body is in the esophagus

 

The next step should be to endoscopically removing those batteries as they lead to tissue necrosis by liquefactive necrosis.

 

Patient’s oral intake should be prohibited until the location of the foreign body is confirmed. Never induce vomiting in these patients as it can again lodge back in the esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove with bronchoscopy: Bronchoscopy is not suitable as the foreign body is located in the esophagus, not the airways.

 

Option C. Reassure and check whether passed in stools: This approach is inappropriate due to the urgent risk of tissue damage from the battery; immediate removal is necessary.

 

Option D. Induce vomiting: Inducing vomiting is contraindicated as it can cause further esophageal injury or lead to re-lodgement of the battery in the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected ingestion of button batteries as seen on CXR, urgent endoscopic removal is critical to prevent tissue damage and potential complications. Vomiting should never be induced in these situations as it can exacerbate the problem.

choices.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factors II, VII, IX, and X

 

Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X are zymogens of serine proteases that contain glutamic acid residues. These residues undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation via gamma-glutamyl carboxylase to form gamma-carboxy glutamic acid residues. This enables them to bind calcium ions (Ca2+), which is necessary for their activation and subsequent blood clot formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factors II, VIII, IX, X: Factor VIII is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is involved in the intrinsic pathway of coagulation but does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option C. Factors II, VII, IX, XI: Factor XI is not a zymogen that requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. It is activated by thrombin and does not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Option D. Factors II, VIII, X, XI: Neither Factor VIII nor Factor XI are zymogens that require gamma-glutamyl carboxylase. They do not undergo vitamin-K-dependent carboxylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zymogens are the proprotein form of enzymes (proenzymes) that require proteolytic activation to carry out their function.

 

Inactive form of vitamin K acts as a cofactor in the post-synthetic modification of these zymogens and their activation. This inactive form of vitamin K is recycled back from its oxidized form by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which can be inhibited by warfarin or liver failure.

choices.text: All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic
Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came to the hospital with a history of trauma to the ear. On examination, there is swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Resolves spontaneously

 

A hematoma of the auricle is depicted in the image given.

 

The scenario described seems to suggest a case of auricular hematoma, which is a collection of blood in the perichondrial space of the ear, usually following trauma. Here is a breakdown of the options provided:

 

This statement is false regarding Perichondral hematoma . If an Perichondral hematoma is left untreated, it usually does not resolve spontaneously. Instead, it often requires intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the development of 'Cauliflower ear'. The standard treatment involves aspiration of the hematoma or surgical intervention to prevent permanent deformity and to reestablish the connection between the cartilage and the overlying perichondrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic: While not all cases may strictly require prophylactic antibiotics, they are often administered in practice to prevent infection, especially because the ear cartilage is avascular and therefore more susceptible to infection. The effectiveness of prophylactic antibiotics is debated, but it is a common practice, particularly when there's been a break in the skin.

 

Option B. May lead to Pugilistic ear: This is true. A 'Pugilistic ear' is another term for 'Cauliflower ear', which can occur if an auricular hematoma is not adequately treated, leading to fibrosis and cartilage deformity.

 

Option C. Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: This is correct. An auricular hematoma occurs when blood accumulates in the space between the cartilage and the perichondrium, which can occur after a blunt trauma to the ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondral hematoma (cauliflower ear, wrestler's ear, or pugilistic ear):

 

  • It is a deformity of the ear brought on by repeated trauma.
  • Perichondral space refers to the area of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium.
  • Due to blunt trauma, it is frequently observed in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players.
  • It does not resolve spontaneously.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered in all cases.
  • Under strict aseptic guidelines, aspiration of the hematoma and application of a pressure dressing to stop re-accumulation.
  • Aspiration might have to be done again. Aspiration that doesn't work should be followed by incision and drainage.

 

Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470424/

questions.text: Which nerve is biopsied for the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic leprosy? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial branch of radial nerve

 

Superficial branch of radial nerve is most commonly used for nerve biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy.

 

Pure neuritic leprosy is characterized by asymmetrical involvement of peripheral nerve trunks without visible skin lesions.

 

  • To confirm the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy, nerve biopsy is considered the gold standard. It is essential to biopsy only sensory nerves and avoid motor or major nerve trunks, as well as mixed nerves.
  • For nerve biopsy in neuritic leprosy, the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is typically utilized.

 

 

  • The biopsy sample should be taken from a purely sensory thickened peripheral nerve, such as the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve at the wrist, ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border of the base of the hand, or sural nerve near the ankle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve and Option C. Ulnar nerve are less frequently chosen for biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy due to their mixed sensory and motor functions, which could lead to functional deficits if damaged.

 

Option D. Lateral popliteal nerve also known as the common peroneal nerve, is generally avoided in routine nerve biopsies for leprosy due to its deeper location and the significant motor components it controls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic Leprosy, the superficial branch of the radial nerve is the preferred site for biopsy due to its accessibility, lower risk of complications, and high diagnostic yield.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.11 28.14

Sensory reanimation of the hand by transfer of the superficial branch of the radial nerve to the median and ulnar nerve - Scientific Figure on ResearchGate. Available from: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Transfer-of-the-superficial-branch-of-the-radial-nerve-SBRN-to-the-median-nerve-MN_fig5_309138539 [accessed 9 Nov, 2023]

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the CT scan? (INCET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior ethmoidal canal  

 

Explanation:

 

Anterior ethmoidal canal is noted by the marked arrows. The anterior ethmoidal canal can be recognized by the fact that it lies below the ethmoidal air cell roof. To prevent bleeding from this vessel during sinus procedures, it is crucial to recognize that the anterior ethmoidal artery runs via this canal. Maxillary sinus is noted in this view hence suggesting anterior plane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The posterior ethmoidal artery, vein, and nerve pass via the ethmoid bone’s posterior ethmoid canal or foramen. Due to the fact that this image is a coronal section taken at the level of the anterior ethmoidal cells, it cannot be seen.

 

Option C. The optic nerve can be identified as an oval intraorbital structure in the coronal sections.

 

Option D. The cribriform plate is a sieve-like structure between the nasal cavity and the anterior cranial fossa. It is part of the ethmoid bone and as it is pierced by the olfactory nerve fibers. Crista Galli is also a part of ethmoid bone that projects superiorly from the cribriform plate. It provides attachment for the falx cerebri.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior ethmoidal canal is critical to identify during sinus procedures to avoid complications such as bleeding from the anterior ethmoidal artery. It is located below the roof of the ethmoidal air cells and anterior to the posterior ethmoidal canal.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HSV2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) typically presents with painful genital vesicles and can cause painful lymphadenopathy. HSV2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is known for causing recurrent outbreaks of painful vesicular lesions in the genital area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:


HSV2 infection is characterized by painful genital vesicles and can be associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, night fever and chills, calf tenderness, cervical lymphadenopathy, hypokalemia, and joint pain. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Leptospirosis is the Ans.  because the patient's presentation of symptoms, particularly conjunctival suffusion (redness of the conjunctiva), is more characteristic of Leptospirosis than the other conditions listed. This condition is caused by the Leptospira bacteria, which can lead to symptoms like retro-orbital pain, night fevers, chills, calf tenderness, and hypokalemia, all seen in this patient.

 

The key differentiator in this case is conjunctival suffusion, which is commonly observed in Leptospirosis and is not a typical feature of Dengue or other listed conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Malaria usually presents with high fevers, chills, sweats, and headache but does not typically cause conjunctival suffusion or calf tenderness. Additionally, hypokalemia is not a common feature of Malaria.

 

Option C. Filariasis: Filariasis is characterized by lymphatic dysfunction and can cause lymphedema or elephantiasis, but it does not present with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, or the other acute symptoms described in the patient.

 

Option D. Dengue: Dengue can present with similar symptoms such as retro-orbital pain, fever, and joint pain, making it a close differential. However, conjunctival suffusion is not a characteristic feature of Dengue, which helps to distinguish it from Leptospirosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival suffusion is a distinguishing symptom of Leptospirosis and is not commonly seen in Dengue or other similar infectious conditions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid

 

Painful genital ulcer is caused by Chancroid.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: The primary lesion of syphilis, known as a chancre, is typically painless. It is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum and usually presents as a firm, round, and painless ulcer.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis infection can cause genital ulcers but these are generally painless and associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). Chlamydia can cause urethritis, cervicitis, and other non-ulcerative conditions but is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is a chronic infection of the lymphatic system caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. The primary lesion is usually a painless genital ulcer or papule, which may go unnoticed by the patient.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibition

 

Vitamin K Dependent Carboxylase is microsomal enzyme. It requires oxygen, CO2, NADPH and reduced vitamin K. In this process, the vitamin passes through a cycle. This process is competitively inhibited by warfarin and dicoumarol.

 

 

Vitamin K cycle

 

Dicoumarol - Structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicide inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds irreversibly to the enzyme, inactivating it permanently.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol does not irreversibly inactivate vitamin K reductase.

 

Option C. Noncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site, altering the enzyme's activity.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol competes at the active site, not at a different site.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibition:

  • Definition: The inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing the reaction from proceeding.
  • Relevance: Dicoumarol binds to the enzyme regardless of the presence of the substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by competitively inhibiting vitamin K reductase, preventing the regeneration of active vitamin K necessary for blood clotting.

questions.text: A 65-year-old guy arrives with tense, itchy bullae over his limbs. The roof of the bullae collapsed after a few days. What is the most likely diagnosis shown in the clinical image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous pemphigoid

 

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

 

  • Elderly aged people are usually affected.
  • It presents as tense itchy bulla, which do not rupture easily, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & the roof of the bullae collapses after a few days forming settled bulla, autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP 230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes are seen in these patients.
  • It is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.
  • Histopathology: subepidermal bullae with eosinophils
  • DIF: deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction in a linear pattern.
  • It is mainly treated with Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is another autoimmune blistering disorder. However, the blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid and easily ruptured as shown in the image below, as opposed to the tense bullae seen in bullous pemphigoid. Additionally, the oral mucosa is frequently involved in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) and presents with itchy papules, vesicles, and bullae. However, the distribution is typically on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees as shown in the image below, and the appearance differs from what is shown in the image in the MCQ.

 

 

Option D. Linear IgA dermatosis: This is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder. The blisters are typically in a "string of pearls" or annular arrangement as shown in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Bullous Pemphigoid is a subepidermal blistering disorder predominantly affecting the elderly, characterized by tense itchy bullae, autoantibodies against BP180 and BP230, and eosinophilic involvement."

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50, Page no. 50.4-50.37.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium

 

  • Glycogen phosphorylase is primarily activated indirectly by calcium ions. An increase in intracellular calcium levels triggers the activation of phosphorylase kinase, which, in turn, activates glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium acts as a secondary messenger to stimulate this cascade of enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6 Phosphate: Glucose 6-phosphate, a product of glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown), actually inhibits glycogen phosphorylase. It is part of a negative feedback mechanism to prevent excessive glycogen breakdown when glucose levels are sufficient.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. Instead, insulin plays a role in promoting glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase and inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase.

 

 

Option D. Glucose: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose signal that glucose is available for energy production, leading to the inhibition of glycogenolysis and glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase is activated indirectly through the calcium signaling pathway, which initiates a series of enzymatic reactions ultimately leading to the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. This mechanism allows the regulation of glycogen breakdown in response to cellular energy needs.

questions.text: Which causative agent is responsible for the 4-year-old boy's condition, characterized by painful mouth sores, a rash on the hands, and fever as shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackievirus

 

The above scenario is suggestive of hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16).CV‐A6 and EV71 are also other important causative organisms.

 

  • Age group commonly affected: Children.
  • Spread: Droplets / fecal contamination.
  • Incubation period: 7 days.
  • Clinical features: In children, the onset is with a low‐grade fever, sore throat and malaise but in adults, a painful stomatitis is an early feature. 
    • Blisters in the mouth soon break down to superficial ulcers.
    • Children are more likely than adults to develop flaccid greyish 2–5 mm oval vesicles on the palms and slightly less frequently on the soles.
  • They fade after 2–3 days. Infection can be subclinical.
  • Only symptomatic treatment is given.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pox virus:

 

  • Poxviruses cause diseases such as smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, which have very different clinical presentations from HFMD.
  • Smallpox, which has been eradicated, presented with a characteristic vesicular and pustular rash and high mortality.
  • Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by firm, painless, umbilicated papules, not the presentation seen in the images provided.

 

Option C. HHV-7 (Human Herpesvirus-7):

 

  • HHV-7 is associated with roseola, a viral infection characterized by a high fever and a rash.
  • HHV 7 is also associated with Pityriasis rosea.
  • However, it does not typically cause painful mouth sores or a rash on the hands.

 

Option D. Parvovirus: Parvovirus B19 can cause a condition called fifth disease, which may result in a rash on the face classically described as slapped cheek appearance as shown in the below image

 

 

but parvo virus not known for causing painful mouth sores or a rash on the hands. Additionally, fifth disease is more common in children between 5 and 15 years old, so it is less likely in a 4-year-old.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of fever, painful oral sores, and a vesicular rash on the hands and feet in a young child is characteristic of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease, which is most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus.

 

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 25 Page no 25.81, chapter 117, Page no 117.6

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1591

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here’s an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.
